docs.lead_paragraph: HELMAND, Afghanistan -- The two worst parts of a deployment are the flights to and from theater. On the way there you're asking, "What the hell am I getting myself into?" And on the way back, you're hoping to God the plane doesn't crash after all you've made it through.

docs.lead_paragraph: Justin Pagan, a seventh grader at the Lower Manhattan Community Middle School, ''barely'' liked reading, he said - until he discovered the Bluford series. With the Bluford books, Justin's classmate Wilson Velez explained, ''The thing is, you want to keep reading it because the drama never gets old.'' So what are these books about?

headline.main: Urban Literary Hit, From Unlikely Source

docs.abstract: City Room blog on Bluford series, collection of 18 books about life at fictional Bluford High School, by Paul Langan; says that many educators who praise the books as gateway to literature also have some reservations about the books' mature content; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Justin Pagan, a seventh grader at the Lower Manhattan Community Middle School, "barely" liked reading, he said - until he discovered the Bluford series. With the Bluford books, Justin's classmate Wilson Velez explained, "The thing is, you want to keep reading it because the drama never gets old."

headline.main: Behind Books for Urban Students, an Unlikely Author

docs.abstract: In the Schools: The Bluford series has captivated its target audience, black and Latino urban middle and high school students who are struggling readers, but the man responsible for the series is a white suburbanite.
docs.snippet: In the Schools: The Bluford series has captivated its target audience, black and Latino urban middle and high school students who are struggling readers, but the man responsible for the series is a white suburbanite.

docs.lead_paragraph: About a year ago, Patricia Garcia, 5 feet tall and 261 pounds, had allowed herself to become the lead character in an article in The New York Times about the rise in maternal obesity, and how it was putting the health of mothers and babies in jeopardy and forcing hospitals to adapt.

headline.main: A Mother's Life Is Taken, as She Feared

docs.abstract: Before she gave birth prematurely last May, Patricia Garcia worried that because of her obesity and related health conditions, she would die before her baby was grown; her prediction came true Sunday.Her prediction came true Sunday,

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials shut down a “maternity tourism” house in California where, they say, Chinese women paid tens of thousands of dollars to stay and deliver their babies, making the infants automatic American citizens.

headline.seo: Officials Close ‘Maternity Tourism’ House in California
headline.main: Arriving as Pregnant Tourists, Leaving With American Babies
